The USGS or the U.S. Government shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein."
Mainstem rivers are the backbone of a connected network of hydrologic units that cover the landscape. A mainstem connects a headwater source area to an outlet. This data release identifies the same mainstem paths in hydrographic datasets for the conterminous US.
descript.purpose: Persistent, cross-scale, identification of hydrologic features, network navigation, and hydrologic indexing (hydrographic addressing).

attracc.attraccr: Attribute accuracy is primarily dependent on source datasets. In cases where major network connections were not present or were directed to the wrong basin, the "next downstream hydrologic unit" attribute (TOHUC) in the Watershed Boundary Dataset were adjusted to match the NHDPlusV2 network.

dataqual.logic: Logical consistency was check with numerous automated validations throughout the workflow software. Manual inspection of the dataset was conducted to verify major rivers are represented correctly. The number of features in the dataset precluded complete manual QA/QC.
dataqual.complete: All mainstem rivers that could be identified in both the 12-digit watershed boundary dataset (see latest WBD input) and the NHDPlusV2 are included. In areas where hydrologic connectivity is ambiguous or a match between the WBD and NHDPlusV2 could not be established, no mainstem rivers are included.

procstep.procdesc:
Match level paths in the NHDPlusV2 and WBD.
The NHDPlusV2 network with eNHD and NWM updates was used to validate and quality control the connectivity of the NHDPlusV2 WBD snapshot and the latest WBD snapshot. In this phase of processing, hydrologic unit topology (downstream connectivity attributes) were adjusted in places where tracing from a headwater hydrologic unit to outlet produced a path different than that found through spatial intersection of the downstream path implied by the NHDPlusV2. This algorithm is implemented in the function match_levelpaths().
Once corrected, the resulting paired paths of hydrologic units were saved to a csv file. Two outputs were produced, one for the NHDPlusV2 snapshot (nhdplusv2wbd.csv) and one for the latest WBD snapshot (newwbd.csv). These CSV files can be joined to the HUC12 field of their respective WBD datasets.

Match flow paths in the NHDPlusV2 and RF1.
The NHDPlusV2 catchments and flowline network with eNHD and NWM updates was used with the eRF1 geometry to find matching mainstem flowpaths in both datasets. For every eRF1 headwater, a representative headwater in the NHDPlusV2 was found. Using this as the starting place, a downstream trace was retrieved from the NHDPlusV2 network and a matching trace retrieved from the eRF1 network. Dominant downstream paths were then established as a method of deduplicating overlapping flowpath traces using NHDPlusV2 network attributes to determine dominance. This flowpath trace is implemented in the match_flowpath() function of the mainstems package.
The resulting mainstem river paths were written to rf1.csv and can be joined to the ID field of the eRF1 dataset.

Match mainstems in NHDPlusV2 and NHDPlusV1
Mainstems in the NHDPlusV1 were established using the published crosswalk between the NHDPlusV1 and NHDPlusV2. Where mappings were ambiguous, no maintem river association was made. The logic for this step can be found in "3_setup.R".
The output of this step is written to the overall mainstems summary table.

Create mainstems summary table
The results of previous processing steps are used to create a single table summarizing all identified mainstem rivers. The primary identifier for a mainstem in this table is the levelapath id from the ENHD-NWM-Network. A headwater and outlet identifier is included for each of the five included datasets (NHDPlusV1, NHDPlusV2, NHDPlusV2 WBD, latest WBD, and eRF1.2). The GNIS ID and Name of the outlet of the mainstem is also included and is derived from NHDPlusV2 attributes. Two geomorphic attributes are included: total drainage area in square kilometers and the stream level as indicated by the mainstems network. A heavily simplified representative geometry based on the NHDPlusV2 flowline collection that makes up the mainstem is included for rudimentary visualization purposes. Any geoprocessing should rely on source datasets only.
This processing step uses cached output of the previous steps. Inspect the workflow runner code for details.
